text:
The king of the big-box-store. If cheap pressboard, self assembly is your thing, it's for you. If you want quality and personal service, go to a locally owned shop.
We went for food, couldn't eat a lot due to my MSG allergy.
Hours to get through the maze of furniture, if you go, be prepared to invest an afternoon shopping.
Really good food and it's cool to go there and dream about how you can transform your home. So much stuff in there! And don't forget to go in the "As It Is" section.

Honestly, if there's one place that I try to avoid at all cost... it would be IKEA. Don't get me wrong, I like what they do, although the quality of some of their products can be questionable, they make modern furniture affordable and that's always a plus. However, I am not a shopping fan... I just want to get what I need and run out, but with IKEA's maze concept, it kinda makes this a little bit difficult plus there's always crowds and crowds of people.

I'm moving into a new place so the sleeping interior designer in me had to make that little effort (having a sofa or kitchen table could always be useful lol). I had never been to that location and honestly, it is better in terms of layout and space than the one in Montreal (at least that's my opinion). The staff is very helpful and seemed happy to assist me with my 1,000 questions. When I got a little bit hungry, I went to their cafeteria and tried their veggie "meatballs" and I really enjoyed it... so much that I've purchased two bags of it. 

I've noticed that they also have a kid zone at the entrance (like all the other IKEA stores that I've visited so far), which is always nice, not all kids enjoy long shopping hours! :-)

Je ne suis pas une fan d'IKEA, trop immense pour moi mais je dois avouer que celui de Boucherville mérite ses 5 étoiles. Le service est excellent, autant sur le plancher qu'à la caisse..ca valait la peine de survivre à l'expérience.

Bon choix, variés, pas trop chers, j'y retournerai

Ikea...the amusement park for home owning adults.

Despite getting lost every time you visit (no matter what location), and getting suckered into buying 1000000 tea-lights because they're right there when you stand in line to pay, we all have a warm place in our heart for it. 

$0.75 hotdogs and the Swedish meatballs might be why, or all the funny (totally NOT Swedish) names for their do-it-yourself furniture.

Fün!

Ah IKEA! Le meilleur ami des étudiants et des plus grands.
3 choses à savoir avant d'y aller : 

1. Prévoir plusieurs heures, à moins de savoir exactement ce que vous voulez, et encore là.
2. Éviter les weeks-end si vous le pouvez, sinon choisissez une journée particulièrement clémente de l'automne où tout le monde est aux pommes.
3. Comme dans toute chose, si ce n'est pas cher, c'est cheap. Un divan à 300$ ça dépanne, mais ça ne toffe pas 10 ans ;) Par contre, il y a aussi des items plus haut de gamme, mais il faut savoir sortir le $$

Ah, un Ikea... tous pareils? Non, celui-ci est à Boucherville sur la rive sud de Montréal. Pour vous y rendre, vous devrez affronter les hordes de banlieusard en quête de ces amas de magasins qui forment les "no man's land" de périphérie. Un vrai cauchemar la fin de semaine, il est possible de s'y rendre sans trop de heur si on choisi méticuleusement une heure stratégique, de jour, loin des heures de pointes, en ayant planifier soigneusement son tracé pour tenter d'éviter les travaux de réfections routier.

Tout cela relève presque du miracle! Si vous y arriver vivant, vous passerai des heures à tenter de trouver le proverbial objet qui fera de votre demeure un endroit de plus ou le design suédois à bon marché s'est infiltré.

Il faut dire que kit pour kit, ceux d'Ikea sont quand même plus simple à réussir que d'autres options qui m'eussent séduite jadis et qui faillirent causer ma perte.

Il est aussi conseiller de se ravitailler à mi-parcours dans leur café avec leurs fameuses boulette de viandes (qui contiennent le plus souvent du boeuf, bien qu'il semble y avoir de l'insertion de viande de cheval de temps en temps... comme quoi le contrôle de qualité suédois n'est pas toujours à l'abri de sous-traitants astucieux!).

This location is the OG IKEA for me. I've been many times and quite enjoy their fish and chips plate. I like their soups and garlic bread and veggie potato pancake thing. I also love their DAIM chocolate and cake - everything is affordable. The only gross thing I've tried there is their vegetarian meatball plate. 

Apart from that, the layout can be a little confusing at times, especially if you're trying to back-track without having to do the full loop again.

This place gets really crowded so I avoid weekends like the plague.

This is your usual Ikea warehouse, and one of the most popular in the province of Quebec.

The good: Prices are good. Lots and lots of expositions and room simulation. Personnel always around to help you. 

The bad: Very very busy! Hard to walk around because it is so busy. Looks and feels like a warehouse, therefore everything is out of place. Some things the prices are too high, you have to know your stuff. Easy to bang your furniture before getting it into your vehicle. Parking is TERRIBLE!!!

Everyone knows that when you go to Ikea, you are due for an adventure, buy lots and lots of stuff, and not go back again until truly necessary.

Have recently done quite a few trips to this Ikea and it has been good every time! We usually like to get there early and enjoy the super cheap basic breakfast (1$!!!) and then get stuck into shopping. Ikea is known for its minimal contemporary designs at affordable prices so its great for first time home buyers!
It is super easy to navigate around the place and find what you need. I love the self-checkout system also as if you go frequently for small or medium items, its very easy and faster to use.
The only area I would improve are the elevator systems (only one elevator to go down to the Marketplace and one to entrance) as it can get quite confusing and if its a busy day, you can be waiting some time. Other than that, it has always been one of my favourite home accessories store and I will be doing some more visits again soon!

Vous avez besoin d'un meuble ou d'un accessoire de maison, Ikea est l'endroit qu'il vous faut. Inutile d'énumérer ce qu'il y a là bas, il y a de tout et pour tous les goûts. Vous vous dites: "J'ai les enfants, sa me tente pas de me casser la tête à les surveiller et de ne pas pouvoir magasiner convenablement." Pas de problème, il y a un service de garderie qui facilitera votre magasinage. Vous avez faim? La aussi il n'y a pas de problème, il y a un service de restauration avec plusieurs choix au menu. Le prix versus la qualité des items en vente est raisonnable. Bon magasinage.

Ma boutique fétiche pour trouver de beaux articles décos à bas prix ! Okay tout le monde connait le IKEA alors je n'ai pas besoin de vanter le prix des articles, mais honnêtement ils sont durs à battre niveau qualité prix ! Nous achetons souvent là-bas et je n'ai eu aucun problème avec quoi que se soit jusqu'à maintenant ! Pour les accents décos, je vous suggère de faire le tour des petites boutiques alentour de chdz vous, mais pour l'essentiel, le IKEA est l'endroit par excellence !!

Votre frère vient de déménager dans un 2 et demi, a besoin de meubles désespérément, mais possède un budget minable? Alors, allez chez Ikea!

Ici, c'est le parfait royaume du meuble en kit! Il y a de tout pour tous les goûts. Vous êtes fatigués? Faites une pause à la cafétéria. Profitez--en pour dévorer leurs célèbres boulettes à la suédoise. Les enfants vous énervent? Il y a toujours le parc de balles multicolores pour les abandonner le temps de faire vos emplettes. 

La seule chose qui manque, ce serait une place pour les ti--vieux, mais bon, cela ne serait tarder avec le vieillissement de la population...

Entre deux marionnettes, couchée sur un lit, j'y ai passé un bon moment...

Love this place. Went there do get stuff fo a walk-in closet and walked out of there in no time at all. THe staff was super friendly and helpful, gave me ideas and different options. It's definitely worth going there if you are going to renovate areas of your place when they are having their sales! 15% cash back is always a nice little gift when you have furnished your whole house with Ikea!!! I'm always there and I always find more stuff to buy! love it!!

Beautiful selection of stuff - just wish there was more staff around to help you. They're definitely not the type to approach you for any assistance so when it's packed, it's hard to flag someone down.

I came in looking for a specific chair that I found through the ikea site, according to store availability, there were supposed to be 8 units left in stock but when I went to the store on the same day, I was told the inventory was inaccurate. This isn't an item that is available for online purchase either and I was told they may only get more in a month, no mention of putting anything on reserve or getting a call for when to come back. Disappointed I went out of my way for it, but at least I found some other nice things. Impossible to walk out of Ikea empty handed.

I especially love the food here, so cheap and delicious.  2$ pasta dishes, salmon for 7$, buns for a dollar, etc.. And refilling your own glass with as much soda, juice, milk or coffee is also a plus. Even if you're not coming to buy furniture, just come have breakfast or lunch, it's worth it.
They have a very spacious cafeteria that makes for an ideal resting spot- Updated summer 2014, they now offer free wifi too.

DIY planning to build or renovate a kitchen need to try Ikea.  I have purchased half a dozen kitchens from here and having shopped all around I can tell you that this is the best bang for your buck solution.
I find they have a lot of different styles, the quality is very good (like I said I have had some experience buying and using their kitchens), and because it is so cheap you can actually change it in 5 years (because you decide your taste have changed) and not break the bank.
Things you must know: You should have an experience person taking the measurements (cause once it is cut it is yours no changes), remember that everything here is straight, so if your new place is like a lot of places (on the plateau for example), then you will need to shimmy and consider the fact that your wall is crooked not the cabinets.  So take your time.
There are often delays due to backorders, so allow some leaway in your timing, or you may end up with an issue, the safest way to go about this is to ensure your installer has some flex time and order well in advance, remember they will store it for a grace period so better safe then sorry.
The Ikea installers are safer but more expensive
Be prepared to spend at least 4 hours at Ikea to pick out your kitchen with the Ikea designers, it is not a fast project but it is a very satisfying one.  Be sure you have all your measurments, (checked twice or three times), if your using a contractor bring him and her along.
tip: be sure to always check their tel quel section they have one in any Ikea.
